article:
Washington, Jan. 21: US Senator Kamala Devi Harris, 54, announced Monday that she is running for President in 2020, joining an alreadycrowded field of Democrats who are making or considering bids to take on Donald Trump.

“The future of our country depends on you and millions of others lifting our voices to fight for our American values. That’s why I’m running for President of the US,” the senator representing California said

in a video posted on Twitter. When she took oath as senator in 2017, the former prosecutor was the first woman of South Asian descent ( her mother is a Tamil Indian) and the second black woman senator in American history. “Justice. Decency. Equality. Freedom. Democracy. These aren’t just words. They’re the values we as Americans cherish. And they’re all on the line now,” Ms Harris added in the video.

She casts herself as a champion of middle class families and her rich mixture of heritage has led some supporters to refer to her as “the female Barack Obama.”

Washington, Jan. 21: Kamala Harris, the first Indian- origin senator, Monday officially launched her campaign for the US presidential election in 2020 to take on President Donald Trump, saying she was “honoured” to announce her bid on a day when Americans celebrated Martin Luther King Jr who sought inspiration from Mahatma Gandhi.

A rising party star and vocal critic of President Trump, Harris, 54, is the fourth Democrat to join the battle for the party’s nomination in the 2020 election.

“I am running for president,” Harris said in a tweet along with a simultaneously released video message.

“Kamala Harris: For the People” is the theme of her campaign.

If elected, she would be the first woman and woman of colour to be the president of the United States.

“I love my country. This is a moment in time that I feel a sense of responsibility to stand up and fight for the best of who we are,” she told a news agency.
summary: US Senator Kamala Harris announced her candidacy for the 2020 presidential election, becoming the fourth Democrat to enter the race. Harris, the first Indian-origin and second Black woman senator in American history, framed her campaign around justice, equality, and democracy. She positions herself as a champion of middle-class families and has been dubbed the “female Barack Obama” by supporters. If elected, she would be the first woman and woman of color to become US president.

headline: US designates Pakistani group LeT's proxy The Resistance Front as global terrorists over Pahalgam attack
article:
The US has designated The Resistance Front (TRF), a proxy of Lashkar-e-Taiba, as a Foreign Terrorist Organization over its role in the April 22 Pahalgam massacre in Kashmir that killed 26 civilians. The United States on Thursday (July 17) designated The Resistance Front (TRF) as a Foreign Terrorist Organization (FTO) and Specially Designated Global Terrorist (SDGT), citing its role in the April 22 Pahalgam massacre in Kashmir that killed 26 civilians.

Announcing the designation, Secretary of State Marco Rubio described TRF as a “front and proxy” of the Pakistan-based Lashkar-e-Taiba (LeT), which is already listed as a terrorist group by both the United Nations and the United States.

“These actions demonstrate the Trump administration’s commitment to protecting our national security interests, countering terrorism, and enforcing President Trump’s call for justice for the Pahalgam attack,” Rubio said in a statement.

Pahalgam massacre triggers global outrage
The Pahalgam terror attack shocked the region. Survivors told media that armed militants targeted Hindu civilians, reportedly separating women and children before ordering male victims to recite the Muslim declaration of faith. Most of the 26 victims were Hindus.

TRF claimed responsibility for the massacre shortly after, though little was previously known about the group, a “smokescreen” created by LeT to operate under a different name and mask its Pakistan-based support.

India strikes back, Pakistan denies role
In response to the Pahalgam killings, India launched Operation Sindoor, targeted strikes on terror networks across the Line of Control and into Pakistani territory. While Islamabad condemned the violence, it denied any connection to the attack or to TRF’s operations.

The US designation puts additional pressure on Pakistan to crack down on terror proxies operating from its soil. It also enables US authorities to block TRF’s assets and prohibit material support to the group.

The announcement marks a significant diplomatic step by the Trump administration, which has repeatedly signaled closer security ties with India amid shared concerns about regional terrorism and cross-border militancy.
summary: The U.S. has designated The Resistance Front (TRF), a Lashkar-e-Taiba proxy, as a Foreign Terrorist Organization following its role in the April 22 Pahalgam massacre that killed 26 civilians in Kashmir. The move increases pressure on Pakistan and strengthens U.S.-India counterterrorism ties amid rising cross-border militancy concerns.

headline: Cong MLA sacked after ‘ bid to murder’
article:
Bengaluru, Jan. 21: A red- faced Congress in Karnataka Monday suspended its MLA J. N. Ganesh, who was also slapped with a case of attempt to murder for allegedly hitting his lawmaker colleague Anand Singh during an alleged brawl at a private resort here on Saturday night.

A day after the incident came to light, the case was registered on a complaint by Mr Singh, who has been hospitalised for an injury he suffered in the alleged brawl at Eagleton Resorts where the Congress MLAs wer...
summary: The Congress party in Karnataka suspended MLA J.N. Ganesh following an alleged brawl at Eagleton Resorts, where he reportedly attacked fellow MLA Anand Singh. Singh filed an attempt-to-murder complaint and was hospitalized with injuries from the incident. The case has been registered, causing embarrassment for the party just ahead of key political events.

headline: 154 more Keralites arrive from Ukraine
article:
As Operation Ganga progresses, 154 more Keralite students from Ukraine reached India on Wednesday, while efforts continued to ensure the safety of Indians stranded in Kharkiv in the eastern part of the war-torn country.

On Wednesday the Indian Embassy in Kyiv had advised Indian nationals to leave Kharkiv immediately in view of the ''deteriorating situation.''
summary:
As Operation Ganga progresses, 154 more Keralite students from Ukraine reached India on Wednesday, while efforts continued to ensure the safety of Indians stranded in Kharkiv in the eastern part of the war-torn country.

On Wednesday the Indian Embassy in Kyiv had advised Indian nationals to leave Kharkiv immediately in view of the ''deteriorating situation.''

headline: Fed's Powell says policy pivot on track despite 'uncertain' impact of Ukraine war
article:
The Federal Reserve will move forward with plans to raise interest rates this month to try to tame high inflation, but the outbreak of war in Ukraine has made the outlook "highly uncertain" for U.S. central bank policymakers as they plan their next steps, Fed Chair Jerome Powell said on Wednesday.

In prepared remarks for his testimony to the U.S. House of Representatives Financial Services Committee, Mr. Powell reiterated the core Fed narrative that high inflation and an "extremely tight" labour market warrant higher interest rates.
summary:
The Federal Reserve will move forward with plans to raise interest rates this month to try to tame high inflation, but the outbreak of war in Ukraine has made the outlook "highly uncertain" for U.S. central bank policymakers as they plan their next steps, Fed Chair Jerome Powell said on Wednesday.

In prepared remarks for his testimony to the U.S. House of Representatives Financial Services Committee, Mr. Powell reiterated the core Fed narrative that high inflation and an "extremely tight" labour market warrant higher interest rates.

headline: Last total lunar eclipse of the decade glows red around the world
article:
A Super Blood Moon is seen behind the Saint Nicolas Church during a lunar eclipse on Monday in the Czech capital, Prague.
Washington, Jan. 21: An unusual set of celestial circumstances came together over Sunday night and the wee hours of Monday for sky watchers in Europe, Africa and the Americas, where the moon was fully obscured before lighting up again with a faint red glow.

In the streets of Mexico City, Los Angeles and Paris and in the Moroccan desert, moon gazers turned to the sky to observe the phenomenon, around midnight in the Americas, and shortly before dawn in Europe and Africa.
summary: On Monday, sky watchers across Europe, Africa, and the Americas witnessed a rare Super Blood Moon during a lunar eclipse. The moon was fully obscured before glowing with a faint red hue, captivating observers in cities like Mexico City, Los Angeles, Paris, and even the Moroccan desert. This unusual celestial event occurred around midnight in the Americas and before dawn in Europe and Africa, drawing crowds outdoors to admire the spectacle.

headline: Delay likely in realisation of payments from Russia: EEPC
article:
Engineering exporters body EEPC India has sought to caution members to the possibility of a delay in realisation of payments from Russia, which is the biggest export market for Indian engineering goods among the CIS countries.

Exclusion of Russia from the SWIFT payment system would mean delayed payment realisation for exporters, chairman Mahesh Desai said in a release on India’s engineering goods export clocking 31% year-on-year increase in February.
summary:

Exclusion of Russia from the SWIFT payment system would mean delayed payment realisation for exporters, chairman Mahesh Desai said in a release on India’s engineering goods export clocking 31% year-on-year increase in February.

headline: Jain group seeks Centre’s nod to travel to Pakistan
article:
As India–Pakistan tensions and the land border closure post–Covid hold up all religious pilgrimages between the two countries, a group of 22 members of the Jain faith have appealed to the Ministry of Home Affairs to allow them to go to Pakistan to visit a shrine that has been restored after decades.

The group, led by Jalandhar-based activist Sunil Jain, who heads the World Jain-Muslim Interfaith Harmony Council, received visas to travel to Lahore on February 21, which will expire on March 7, unless they receive clearances from the MHA and the Immigration Department to travel via the Atari-Wagah border in Punjab.
summary:
As India–Pakistan tensions and the land border closure post–Covid hold up all religious pilgrimages between the two countries, a group of 22 members of the Jain faith have appealed to the Ministry of Home Affairs to allow them to go to Pakistan to visit a shrine that has been restored after decades.

headline: 4 charge-sheeted for murder of ex‑Manipur minister’s daughter
article: Charges filed against four individuals in connection with the high-profile abduction and killing of the daughter of a former Manipur minister; investigation details and police statements included.
summary: On 2 March 2008, The Indian Express reported that four people were formally charged in the murder of a former Manipur minister’s daughter. The police investigation, which had begun after the victim's body was discovered, uncovered evidence tying the accused to the crime, including eyewitness testimonies and forensic findings. Authorities have detailed the events leading up to the murder, outlining possible motives rooted in local political conflicts. With charges under kidnapping and homicide sections of Indian law, the accused now await trial. The article highlights the difficulty of securing justice in politically sensitive regions like Manipur, where law-and-order issues are often compounded by insurgency-related tensions.

headline: IAF sends four C-17 aircraft for evacuation of Indians
article:
The Indian Air Force (IAF) has launched three C-17 transport aircraft to Romania, Hungary and Poland on Wednesday morning, Air Marshal Sandeep Singh, Vice-Chief of the Air Force, said. A fourth C-17 was sent later in the day. The C-17 was sent as it can fly non-stop to these countries.

“Since early morning three C-17 have been launched. This is being undertaken with full coordination with the Ministry of External Affairs. The operations will go round the clock. We are also sending some supplies from here,” Air Marshal Singh said, speaking to the media at a briefing on upcoming fire power demonstration ‘Ex Vayu Shakti’ on March 07. “I am sure we will bring all of our people back safely.”
summary:
IAF Deploys Four C-17 Aircraft for Ukraine Evacuation Mission

The Indian Air Force (IAF) has intensified its evacuation efforts, launching four C-17 Globemaster transport aircraft to Eastern Europe on Wednesday to rescue Indians stranded in war-torn Ukraine.

headline: Naxalites shift gaze to urban areas, think of car bombs, suicide missions
article: Naxalite insurgency’s strategy review indicating a potential expansion into urban guerrilla tactics, including use of car bombs and suicide missions.
summary: On 3 March 2008, The Indian Express reported that Naxalite insurgents in India were broadening their operational strategy to include urban areas, considering tactics such as car bombs and suicide missions. This shift from traditional rural ambushes to urban terrorism represents a worrying escalation. According to security sources, the group is assessing higher-impact operations to draw attention to their cause and exert pressure on the government. Police forces in cities remain on alert, boosting intelligence campaigns to intercept potential plots. The article analyses how this emerging threat complicates counter‑insurgency measures and may provoke stricter national security responses.

headline: Explained | What are Europe’s ‘ghost flights’, and why are they a problem?
article:
Lufthansa aircraft parked on a runway at the airport in Frankfurt. File | Photo Credit: AP

With the decline in flights for business or pleasure due to the ongoing pandemic, airlines that are attempting to maintain market share are complaining about the ‘ghost flights’ they are being forced to fly.

An EU regulation that dates back to 1993 requires European airlines to maintain empty or near-empty flights just to retain their take-off and landing slots. This is done to avoid the slots from being handed over to other airlines that might be competitors or new market entrants. Usually, these airlines are required to use up to 80 per cent of their slots to secure them. Owing to the pandemic, this threshold was temporarily reduced to 50 per cent of booked flights but as soon as this winter ends in March 2022, it is set to once again increase to 64 per cent. Essentially, airline operators have to prove that they have adequate market demand that justifies their holdings. According to the European Commission’s website, this ‘use it or lose it’ system is employed “to ensure that airlines have access to the busiest EU airports on the basis of principles of neutrality, transparency and non-discrimination.”
summary:
Airlines Forced to Fly 'Ghost Flights' Amid Pandemic Slump Due to EU Slot Rules

European airlines are being compelled to operate near-empty or empty "ghost flights" to retain their valuable airport slots, despite plummeting travel demand during the pandemic.

headline: Bush vetoes bill against waterboarding
article: President George W. Bush exercised a veto to block a Congressional bill that aimed to prohibit the controversial interrogation technique of waterboarding.
summary: On 8 March 2008, The Indian Express reported that U.S. President George W. Bush vetoed a bill passed by Congress to ban waterboarding, a technique widely regarded as torture. The veto underscores the administration’s commitment to maintaining certain enhanced interrogation practices during the “war on terror.” Critics argue that waterboarding violates international human rights norms, while supporters say it is vital for national security. The article explores the political showdown in Washington, with international bodies condemning the veto. It also examines the ethical implications of such interrogation methods and the legal challenges they pose under both U.S. and international law.

headline: India is natural leader of Quad in Indo-Pacific region,’ says Australian High Commissioner
article:
Barry O’Farrell, Australian High Commissioner to India. File | Photo Credit: Dinesh Krishnan

India is clearly the natural leader in the region in terms of the vision the Quad signs up to in the Indo-Pacific region, and the multi-nation defence exercise, MILAN, held in Vishakapatnam demonstrates the cooperation across countries in the Indo-Pacific, Australian High Commissioner to India, Barry O’Farrell said.

“The exercise Milan where 14 countries, including Australia, took part, demonstrates the co-operation across countries in the Indo-Pacific to secure a free, open and prosperous Indo-Pacific. In terms of the vision the Quad signs up to with relation to the Indo-Pacific, India is clearly the natural leader in the region. The good news is that all four countries [India, Australia, USA and Japan] are working together, whether it is on vaccine rollout, disaster relief and other issues like climate change,” Mr. O’Farrell told The Hindu.
summary: Australian High Commissioner to India Barry O’Farrell lauded India’s leadership in advancing the Quad’s vision for a free, open, and prosperous Indo-Pacific, citing the recent MILAN naval exercise in Visakhapatnam (with 14 participating nations, including Australia) as proof of regional collaboration. He emphasized the Quad’s joint efforts on vaccines, disaster relief, and climate change, underscoring India’s pivotal role in the strategic partnership.

headline: GAIL floats CNG‑piped gas arm ahead of unbundling
article: GAIL (India) Ltd. formed a separate division to distribute CNG and piped gas as part of its strategy before the planned unbundling of its operations.
summary: On 11 March 2008, The Indian Express reported that GAIL had established a dedicated subsidiary to oversee its CNG and piped gas operations, preceding the government's planned unbundling of state energy monopolies. This restructuring is part of GAIL’s wider strategy to position itself for regulatory changes and to enhance competitiveness. The new arm is expected to streamline project implementation, attract private investment, and strengthen infrastructure delivery. Industry analysts believe this move signals the start of deeper energy sector reforms, potentially paving the way for increased efficiency, better pricing, and improved access for urban and rural consumers.

headline: Ukrainians say they are fighting on in biggest city yet claimed by Russia
article:
Credit: Reuters

Ukrainians said they were fighting on in the southern port of Kherson, the first sizeable city Russia claimed to have seized, while Russian air strikes and bombardment caused devastation in cities that Moscow's bogged down forces have failed to capture.

After nearly a week, Russia has yet to achieve its aim of overthrowing Ukraine's government, but has, according to the Ukrainian emergency service, killed more than 2,000 civilians and destroyed hospitals, kindergartens and homes.

headline: 42,896 Bangladeshis infiltrated into Assam
article: Official estimates indicate that nearly 43,000 illegal Bangladeshi immigrants had entered Assam, raising concerns over demographic balance and resource pressure.
summary: On 12 March 2008, The Indian Express highlighted government estimates that approximately 42,896 illegal Bangladeshi immigrants had settled in Assam, raising tensions over local resources and social harmony. The article explores the political and community anxieties caused by such large-scale migration, including demands for stricter border control and verification drives. Administrators are under pressure to implement effective measures without infringing on civil rights. The integration of immigrants has additionally heightened fears around employment competition and cultural assimilation. The piece contextualises the issue within Assam’s rise in ethnopolitical activism and regional identity movements.

headline: Hyderabad airport opening: SpiceJet pips Lufthansa
article: SpiceJet outperforms Lufthansa by securing inaugural operations at the new Hyderabad airport; covers inaugural flight details and competitive implications.
summary: On 23 March 2008, The Indian Express reported that SpiceJet was awarded the inaugural commercial flight slot at the newly launched Hyderabad International Airport, surpassing German carrier Lufthansa. The move marks an important moment for the low-cost carrier as it strengthens domestic expansion and brand positioning. The airline’s CEO cited strategic planning and competitive pricing as keys to winning the slot. Lufthansa’s interest signals Hyderabad’s growing appeal as an international gateway. The article examines how this development could reshape air travel in southern India—bringing more competition, better connectivity, and lower fares for travelers.

headline: Indian students fume at embassy’s ‘short notice’ advisory leave Kharkiv
article:
2022. | Photo Credit: Reuters

There is anger and exasperation among hundreds of Indian students and professionals in Kharkiv after the Indian Embassy in Kyiv issued an advisory on Wednesday asking them to leave the city at a “short notice”.

“If the situation was this bad, why did the government not ask us to leave before. Students like me repeatedly asked the government to take some action as the situation was worsening rapidly. But despite these requests nothing happened. And, now students have been asked to leave at such a short notice,” said Bhanvi Bhatia who managed to rush to the main train station in Kharkiv and was lucky to board a train, but she feared for many left behind.
summary: Hundreds of Indian students and professionals stranded in Ukraine’s besieged Kharkiv city expressed fury and frustration after the Indian Embassy issued a sudden advisory urging them to evacuate at "short notice" amid escalating Russian attacks.

headline: EU cuts Russian banks from SWIFT, bans RT, Sputnik
article:
Photo used for representational purpose only. File | Photo Credit: Reuters

The European Union on Wednesday cut seven Russian banks from the SWIFT payment system and banned Kremlin-controlled media outlets RT and Sputnik from broadcasting into the bloc.

The measures, effective immediately, were the latest ratcheting up of the Western-coordinated sanctions on Russia for its invasion of Ukraine, now in its seventh day.

headline: Vaas helps Lanka make history
article: Lasith Malinga’s eight-wicket haul overshadowed as Chaminda Vaas steered Sri Lanka to a historic cricket victory—match summary provided.
summary: On 27 March 2008, The Indian Express celebrated Sri Lankan pacer Chaminda Vaas for “making history” in an extraordinary display of bowling. Vaas delivered a match-defining performance, capturing key wickets that guided Sri Lanka to a memorable triumph in an ODI series. Already renowned as a leading merchant, his unexpected resurgence revived interest in his longevity at the international level. The article includes quotes from teammates praising his spell, and analysts credit his tactical intelligence and fitness discipline. It also discusses the impact on team morale and Sri Lanka’s future bowling prospects.
